Exaggerate: The claim may be seen as an exaggeration because it states that "everybody will have lower rates, better quality care and better access" under the health care law, which may not be entirely accurate or applicable to every individual.
Understate: The claim may understate the potential impact of the health care law by not acknowledging that the personal experience of individuals within each group could be very different, and that the average change in rates may not reflect the affordability for everyone.
Lack enough support: The claim may lack enough support as it does not provide specific evidence or data to back up the assertion that "everybody will have lower rates, better quality care and better access" under the health care law.
Problematic assumption: The claim may rely on a problematic assumption that everyone's insurance needs and preferences will remain the same, without considering the possibility that individuals may want to buy better insurance or have different coverage requirements.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations or perspectives regarding the impact of the health care law on rates, quality care, and access that are not addressed in the claim.
